Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a scan-less temporal focusing two-photon fluorescence microscope for high-speed three-dimensional imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) to develop a high-speed optical microscope for imaging fluorescent objects and simultaneously tracking their fast motion in three-dimensional (3D) space. This interdisciplinary project enriches undergraduate and graduate students' education by providing frontier research experience in the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, and electrical engineering. It also trains postdoctoral researchers who will form the next generation of instrumentalists. This project gives scientists in biology and chemistry a strong background in the development and use of innovative and contemporary
instruments, significantly enhancing their ability to conduct cutting-edge research. The developed microscope will serve as the cornerstone of a Biophotonics core facility that will promote collaborative research, education and outreach activities. Underrepresented minority students at UTEP, a Hispanic-majority (almost 80%) institution, and regional users will be invited to participate in workshops and research activities using this facility.

This project is an innovation in the field of fluorescence microscopy. By integrating two ultrafast laser techniques, temporal focusing and pulse shaping, this new microscope has the capability of acquiring 3D volumetric images at an unprecedented high-speed (50 volumes/s, volume size 100um × 100um × 100um). This microscope eliminates the current laser beam scanning mechanisms typically used in confocal and two-photon microscopes with temporal focusing, and adds depth scanning capability by integrating the pulse shaping technique. This project will also develop a computerized image processing system that will automatically analyze high-speed videos. These capabilities, i.e. high-speed and 3D volumetric imaging, will enable researchers to explore and analyze previously unobtainable fast dynamic information from this automatic image analysis systems. Initial applications are in the areas of marine virus infection, nanoparticle transportation, and fly brain imaging. Applications could extend to many other fields where it is hard to study fast 3D dynamic processes using current laser beam scanning fluorescence microscopes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this grant is to develop a high-speed optical microscope for imaging fluorescent objects, and simultaneously tracking their fast motion in three-dimensional (3D) space. By integrating two ultrafast laser techniques, temporal focusing and pulse shaping (Figure 1), this new microscope has the capability of acquiring 3D volumetric microscopic images at high-speed. This microscope eliminates current laser beam scanning mechanisms typically used in confocal and two-photon microscopes with temporal focusing, and adds depth scanning by integrating the pulse shaping technique. This project also developed image processing software to automatically analyze high-speed images. These capabilities, i.e. high-speed and 3D volumetric imaging, enable researchers to explore and analyze previously unobtainable fast dynamic information from an automatic 3D imaging system. We have applied this system to study a variety of biological and materials science questions. Figure 2 shows the fast predating behavior of marine zooplankton Cafeteria roenbergensis on bacteria. We also studied the distribution of copper oxide nanoparticles inside sweet potato tissue, and visualized 3D printed aluminum nitride ceramic samples under different laser electric field polarization. New software based on geometric symmetry fitting and deep learning have been developed to locate fluorescent molecules and reconstruct images. Further applications could extend to many other fields, where studying fast 3D dynamic processes is necessary. Research results have been disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, and research seminars.

This project enriches undergraduate and graduate students? education by providing frontier research experience and workshop involving multidisciplinary fields, biology, chemistry, physics, and electrical engineering. It also involves training of postdoctoral researchers. This interdisciplinary project also gives future scientists in other disciplines a strong background in the development and implement of innovative instruments, significantly enhancing their ability to conduct cutting edge research. Over the five-year period of this grant, one postdoctoral researcher, ten graduate students, and eight undergraduate students have received training in this project. The successful development of this microscope provides a major instrument in the Biophotonics facility at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), a minority-serving institution with ~80% Hispanic student population. This facility also facilitates collaboration with a nearby institution, New Mexico State University in Las Cruces, New Mexico. Two students trained by this program had acted as science ambassadors reaching out to K-12 students in El Paso public schools. They disseminated the knowledge, and educated students with advanced science and technology development.
